I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed grant 

 
1. 
to Nepal for the Skills Development Project.1
  
 
2. 
The  project  will  help  the  government  implement  key  aspects  of  the  Technical  and 
Vocational  Education  and Training (TVET)  Policy,  2012.2 The  project  will  help  the government 
(i) initiate  strategic  reforms  that  aim  to  improve  overall  management  and  performance  of  the 
TVET system, (ii) improve the quality and relevance of public training, and (iii) increase private 
sector engagement in training delivery and job placement. Each intervention has been designed 
to  increase  the  efficiency  and  results  orientation  of  TVET,  making  it  more  market-driven.  The 
project will focus on skills development for the construction, manufacturing, and services sectors 
where large skill gaps exist.3
  
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

Rationale 

 
A. 
  
3. 
Despite  a  decade  of  conflict  until  2006 followed  by  protracted  political  instability,  Nepal 
has made significant progress in key Millennium Development Goals.4 Gross domestic product 
(GDP)  grew  by  less  than  5%  in  FY2008–FY2012.5 The  government  is  at  a  critical  juncture  to 
meet the aspiration of the people for an improved standard of living and more equitable access 
to  opportunities.  Recent  reports  identify  lack  of  skilled  labor  as  one  of  the  key  constraints  for 
economic growth.6 The economy is undergoing a transition from a largely subsistence, agrarian 
economy  to  a  more  mixed  economy  where  demand  for  basic  to  mid-level  technically  skilled 
workers  is  growing  rapidly,  especially  in  the  services  sector.7
 Having  a  base  of  skilled  young 
people can underpin stronger economic growth, leveraging Nepal’s demographic dividend and 
productivity  gains,  provide  transformational  opportunities  to  individuals,  and  thus  contribute  to 
social stability and national development. 
 
4. 
Human resource potential. Nepal has great potential for a demographic dividend, with 
an age dependency ratio of 65.9% in 2011, high labor force participation of both women (80.2%) 
and  men  (87.7%)  in  2010,  and  high  overseas  demand  for  Nepalese  workers.  Unemployment 
rate  was  2.7%. 8  Annually,  about  450,000  youth  enter  the  labor  market.  Seeking  better 
employment opportunities, about 1,000 Nepalese workers leave for jobs abroad on a daily basis 
in  2011. 9
 Remittances  were  estimated  to  be  about  21%  of  GDP  in  2012.  The  educational 
attainment  of  the  workforce,  however,  is  poor  as  62%  leave  school  by  grade  5,  over  75%  by

 grade  8,  and  about  48%  never  attended  school  (footnote  8).  Overseas  workers  are  mainly 
engaged in low- or no-skilled and low-wage occupations. Nepal experiences skills mismatch in 
the labor market where job seekers do not have the right skills for available vacancies and new 
skills  are  in  demand.  Domestic  employers  report  shortages  of  workers  with  technical  and 
general employability skills.  
 
5. 
Technical  and  vocational  education  and  training.  Formal  TVET  in  Nepal  is  offered 
through 26 public institutes, 75 vocational units attached to district secondary schools, and over 
450  privately  run,  publicly  affiliated  training  providers.  Many  small  unaffiliated  providers  offer 
informal training, and traditional apprenticeships offer informal learning on the job. Constituted in 
1989,  the  Council  for  Technical  Education  and  Vocational  Training  (CTEVT)  has  been 
mandated  to  be  an  autonomous  apex  body  for  TVET,  and  forms  the  backbone  of  the  formal 
TVET  system  in  Nepal  in  terms  of  technical,  regulatory,  and  provision  functions  through  its 
constituent  institutions  and  affiliated  providers.  As  semiautonomous  suborganizations  of  the 
CTEVT,  the  Training  Institute  for  Technical  Instruction  and  the  National  Skills  Testing  Board 
serve the need for TVET human resource development, skills testing, and certification. Several 
government  ministries  also  run  formal  and  informal  programs.  The  number  of  private  training 
providers has increased since the mid-2000s due to high demand for skills with an expectation 
of  higher-paying  jobs.  Government  and  externally  financed  projects  also  offer  short-term 
training.10
  
 
6. 
Constraints. TVET has an important role in transforming Nepal’s human resources into 
productive  assets  to  meet  the  government’s  national  development  objective  for  inclusive, 
employment-oriented growth. Key constraints to TVET sector performance include the following: 
Insufficient  and  inequitable  access.  The  formal  TVET  system  offers  about 
26,000 places at technical school leaving certificate and diploma levels.11 Various 
organizations,  both  private  and  public,  offer  about  60,000  places  in  short-term 
training  opportunities  per  year.12 Considering  the  large  number  of  new  entrants, 
the  current  level  of  access  is  far  from  adequate.  In  addition,  opportunities  are 
concentrated  in  urban  areas  and  women  and  people  from  excluded  groups  still 
face  difficulties  in  access  because  of  the  additional  cost,  opportunity  cost, 
distance, prerequisites, and male-oriented training setup.13
 Gender tracking, i.e., 
a  pattern  that  reinforces  male–female  distinctions  in  occupational  and  income 
disparities, is evident in TVET as female enrollment is much higher in traditionally 
female skills like housekeeping and care giving.  
Poor  quality  and  low  market  relevance.  A  persistent  lack  of  investment  in 
TVET  has  resulted  in  insufficient  and  outdated  equipment,  facilities,  materials, 
and  teaching  force  in  the  public  sector.  In  the  private  sector,  few  providers  are 
able  to  invest  adequately  in  their  facilities  or  scale  up  their  teaching  force 
because  of  unpredictable  business  opportunities  and  price  competition.  The 
industry  relevance  of  TVET  is  low  and  industry  involvement  in  TVET  is  weak—
undermining  the  credibility  of  TVET  qualifications.  There  are  no  formalized 
industry  sector  councils  at  the  national  level,  nor  many  direct  advisory

 committees  at  provider  level.  Public  training  providers  often  have  limited 
understanding  of the  requirements  of the modern  labor market;  courses  are  not 
updated  to  reflect  the  needs  of  employers;  and  few  providers  offer  adequate 
post-training support to assist trainees’ transition to the labor market.  

(iii)   Weak institutional  capacity. The government adopted its TVET policy in 2012, 
signaling a strong commitment and vision for TVET, but the policy framework is 
not  linked  to  national  development  planning  processes,  there  is  no  clear 
implementation  strategy,  and  the  Ministry  of  Education  (MOE)  has  limited 
capacity  in  TVET.  TVET  efforts  are  fragmented,  without  effective  coordination. 
The  CTEVT’s  structure,  functions,  and  organizational  and  human  resource 
capacity remain largely the same as when it was established in 1989. It has both 
regulatory and provision functions, which creates a perceived conflict of interest. 
Public providers lack autonomy in financial and human resource decisions, which 
acts as a disincentive to innovation and entrepreneurship. The number of private 
training providers has recently increased with externally funded projects, but their 
capacity  to  develop  viable  business  by  providing  quality  and  market-relevant 
training is limited.  

 
7. 
Investment  gaps.  The  government  allocated  about  $20  million  for  public  TVET 
provision  in  FY2012  through  various  ministries.  Since  FY2008,  the  government  allocation  has 
increased by 30% annually, mostly spent on recurrent expenditures (i.e., staff salaries), leaving 
little for upgrading or new investment in infrastructure and human resources. Recent estimates 
project  the  annual  financing  requirement  for  73,000  students  (5%  of  general  secondary 
enrollment)  in  the  technical  stream  and  200,000  places  for  basic  training  to  be  more  than 
$110 million by 2016.14
 This is based on the government unit costs for different programs, which 
exclude capital investment, so the actual needs for TVET financing would be even larger.  
 
8. 
Opportunities. The TVET policy envisions critical institutional reforms such as a single-
window  TVET  fund,  a  national  vocational  qualification  framework,  and  a  national  vocational 
qualification  authority.  The  current  political  environment  and  existing  institutional  capacity  are 
not  conducive  for  comprehensive  reforms  or  a  large-scale  investment  to  realize  the  vision. 
However, the CTEVT Act, 1988 is flexible enough to commence key institutional and operational 
reforms  without  regulatory  changes.  The  CTEVT  and  public  and  private  providers  have 
established a base of infrastructure and human resources where catalytic investment can help 
maximize  the  utilization  for  better  efficiency.  These  aspects  offer  ample  opportunities  to 
(i) institute  incremental  reform  that  will  contribute  to  more  coherent  sector  coordination;  and 
(ii) create  an  environment  for  a  vibrant  mix  of  public  and  private  providers  to  apply  innovative 
approaches  to  address  access,  quality,  and  relevance  issues.  As  the  first  externally  funded 
project after the TVET Policy was adopted in 2012, the project will leverage these opportunities, 
aiming  at  incremental  reform  and  instilling  the  focus  on  performance  and  employment  results. 
Informed  by  a  labor market  assessment,  the  project  will  focus  on  construction, manufacturing, 
and services where high demand for basic and mid-level skills exists.15
  
  
Development coordination. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) Skills for Employment

private providers, achieving the target of 60,000 trainees over a 5-year period (footnote 2). The 
Skills  for  Employment  Project  mechanism  has  been  adapted  by  other  projects  such  as  the 
Employment  Fund  (financed  by  the  Department  for  International  Development  of  the  United

 Kingdom,  the  Swiss  Agency  for  Development  and  Cooperation,  and  the  World  Bank)  and  the 
Enhanced Vocational Education and Training (financed by the World Bank). Both projects  use 
similar  performance-based  contracting,  each  delivering  about  10,000–15,000  places  annually. 
The  project  will  augment  these  efforts  in  expanding  access  to  basic  skills  training.  The 
Employment  Fund,  which  has  been  successfully  implemented  outside  of  the  government 
system,  will  end  in  2013  and  the  Employment  Fund  is  exploring  ways  to  transfer  its  good 
practices to the government system. The project will build the capacity of the CTEVT in adapting 
and applying good practices, such as performance-based contracting and rigorous monitoring. 
For the last decade, development partners have not supported the CTEVT’s core organizational 
issues  because  of  its  politicization,  and  the  proposed  incremental  reform  will  provide  an  entry 
point  for  development  partners  to  jointly  support  a  more  comprehensive  reform  in  the  near 
future. 
 
10. 
Lessons. Lessons from the Skills for Employment Project and other projects are (i) that 
training needs assessments focusing on market-driven skills, identification of the right trainees, 
and post-training services are required to ensure better employment outcome and inclusiveness 
targets; (ii) that rigorous monitoring is essential to ensure quality training and minimize fiduciary 
risks;  (iii)  that  TVET  agencies  need  to  build  operational  capacity;  (iv)  that  industry  linkages 
should  be  enhanced  at  the  training  provider  level;  and  (v)  that  CTEVT  constituent  institutions 
should be granted greater autonomy for quality and relevance improvement.  
 
11. 
Key design features. Building on the lessons and leveraging existing opportunities, the 
project  will  adopt  the  following  design  features,  which  aim  at  instilling  strong  results  and 
performance orientation in TVET:

skills  development  initiatives  to  include  (a)  identification  of  skills  demanded,  (b) 
mobilization of potential trainees, (c) training provision itself, and (d) employment 
services.

Gender  and  social  inclusion. The project will aim at increasing the enrollment

(iv)  Monitoring  and  evaluation  and  fiduciary  management.  A  strong  monitoring 
and evaluation (M&E) mechanism, which includes third-party monitoring to verify 
employment  outcomes,  will  reduce  the  fiduciary  risks  involved  in  performance-
based contracts. An annual fiduciary review will complement the internal audit of 
the  CTEVT  and  the  financial  audit  by  the  government’s  Office  of  the  Auditor 
General.  

 
12. 
The project is fully aligned with the Three Year Plan, FY2011–FY2013, which highlights 
the need for more skills training for employment. The project contributes directly to two pillars: (i) 
broad-based  and  inclusive  economic  growth  and  (ii)  inclusive  social  development  in  ADB’s 
country  partnership  strategy,  2010–2012,  and  will  contribute  to  effective  implementation, 

4 

 

 operation,  and maintenance  of ADB  investments  in  energy,  transport,  and  urban  infrastructure 
development by increasing the skilled labor force.16
  

 

Outputs 

Impact and Outcome 

The impact will be increased employability of the Nepalese workforce. The outcome will 

B. 
 
13. 
be the establishment of a market-responsive and social and gender-inclusive TVET system.  
 
C. 
 
Output  1:  Expanded  provision  of  inclusive,  market-oriented  training.  Output 1 will 
14. 
provide  45,000  additional  places  for  market-oriented,  basic  skills  training. 17
 It  will  target 
unemployed  or  underemployed  people,  at  least  40%  of  whom  will  be  women  and  30%  from 
excluded groups. An additional 1,000 places for mid-level skills programs will be created at the 
10  selected  public  providers.  Output  1  will  be  achieved  by  (i)  conducting  awareness  and 
socialization  campaigns  for  potential  trainees;  (ii)  engaging  private  and  public  providers  to 
deliver  training  and  employment  services;  (iii)  using  a  results-based  payment  methodology 
whereby milestone payments are released only upon verification of employment outcomes; and 
(iv) monitoring and evaluating training activities.  
 
15. 
Output 1 aims to close the skills gap by providing basic or mid-level skills for people with 
low  formal  educational  attainment  and  limited  work  experience,  who  will  usually  be  from 
disadvantaged backgrounds. Social mobilization and community outreach will be used to reach 
the  target  group.  About  36,000  seats  will  be  delivered  by  private  training  providers  and  this 
modality  will  further  develop  government  capacity  to  manage  performance-based  contracting. 
Higher  performance  payments  will  be  given  for  training  and  job  placement  for  women  and 
people  from  excluded  groups.  By  tying  50%  of  the  contract  payment  with  employment 
outcomes, this output will encourage private providers to focus more on employment results and 
to  scale  up  their  operations—increasing  their  chances  for  growing  viable  business.  About 
9,000 places will be delivered by public training providers, through a separate mechanism, also 
adopting whole-cycle approach and focusing on employment outcomes. 
 
16. 
Output  2:  Improved  quality  and  relevance  of  technical  and  vocational  education 
and  training  provision.  Output  2  will  improve  the  quality  and  relevance  of  TVET  by 
transforming  10  public  providers  into  more  efficient,  better  managed,  market-driven  model 
institutes  with  close  links  to  labor  market  demand.  It  will  (i)  implement  a  comprehensive, 
tailored,  quality  improvement  program  in  10  selected  public  training  institutions,  turning  them 
into model TVET institutes; (ii) develop 25 new or updated fee-paying mid-level programs in the 
priority  sectors  of  construction,  manufacturing,  and  services  to  be  delivered  in  the  10  model 
institutes;  (iii)  support  refurbishment  and  equipment  purchase  necessary  to  support  quality 
training; (iv) establish industry partnership committees and agreements for industry linkages at 
the 10 model institutes; and (v) provide in-service training for 300 TVET professionals in TVET 
management, occupational skills, instructional skills, and curriculum development.  
 
17. 
The 10 public training institutions have been selected based on geographic spread, non-
overlapping  support  with  the  World  Bank  project,  possibility  of  increasing  enrollment  utilizing 
existing  facilities,  and  strong  management  potential.  Considering  the  diverse  socioeconomic 
characteristics of each region and changing labor market demand, good management capacity 
and  increased  autonomy  at  training  institute  level  is  crucial  to  perform  better.  CTEVT  has

 agreed to allow greater autonomy for the 10 selected providers, including the retention and use 
of a greater percentage of income earned. With targeted management training, institute-specific 
quality improvement plans, and the establishment of direct industry and employer links, the 10 
model  institutes  are  expected  to  develop  into  more  autonomous  and  entrepreneurial  training 
institutes  serving  local  and  industry  needs  and  managing  resources  more  efficiently.  The 
performance  of  these  selected  institutes  will  be  gauged  against  set  quality  criteria,  baselines 
established  at  the  onset  of  the  project,  and  targets  included  in  the  quality  improvement 
programs. In the future, the quality criteria may be developed and form the basis of a stronger 
affiliation  and  registration  system.  Priority  for  the  300  in-service  professional  development 
opportunities will be given to staff within the 10 model institutes and the CTEVT. 
 
18. 
Output  3:  Policy,  institutional,  and  operational reforms  implemented. Output 3 will 
contribute  to  more  effective  management  of  TVET  by  (i)  ensuring  the  TVET  road  map  and 
results framework are updated and in line with national development priorities; (ii) setting up  a 
TVET  sector  development  unit  (TSDU)  within  the  MOE,  which  will  be  responsible  for  overall 
coordination;  (iii)  preparing  the  institutional  framework,  procedures,  and  detailed  terms  of 
reference  of  a  single-window  TVET  fund;  and  (iv)  facilitating  the  CTEVT  to  restructure  in  line 
with emerging labor market demand and services.  
 
19. 
The TVET Policy lays out the government’s vision for TVET with the understanding that 
a  number  of  policy,  institutional,  and  operational  reforms  are  necessary.  TVET  systems  are 
diversifying into training markets with a mix of public, private, industry, or community-managed 
providers. This calls for a changing role of government agencies. The government should take 
the  role  of  facilitator  and  regulator,  allowing  equal  opportunities  for  both  public  and  private 
providers, encouraging more private sector investment in training, and filling any gaps through 
public investment or public–private partnerships. To support such transformation, this output will 
help redefine the roles and strengthen the capacity of the MOE and CTEVT for improved TVET 
management. The output will establish a TSDU within the MOE. The unit will be responsible for 
overall  coordination,  using  the  sector  road  map  and  results  framework  as  the  tools  for 
coordinated  planning,  implementation,  and  M&E.  It  will  also  take  the  lead  to  develop  the 
institutional framework and procedures of a TVET fund as envisaged by the TVET Policy. The 
government  will  make  an  annual  allocation  of  $2  million  from  FY2016  to  be  disbursed  via  the 
TVET  fund  mechanism.  Together  with  the  results  framework,  the  TVET  fund  will  help  the 
government to introduce a sector-wide approach.  
 
20. 
Output  4:  Effective  project  management,  monitoring,  and  evaluation. Output 4 will 
provide the support necessary for effective project management and robust M&E of results. This 
will  be  achieved  by  enabling  the  project  coordination  unit  and  project  implementation  unit  to 
(i) operate a robust M&E mechanism—including establishing five regional M&E teams, a third-
party  monitoring  mechanism  for  employment  verification,  and  an  M&E  database;  (ii)  ensure 
timely  planning,  implementation,  and  reporting;  and  (iii)  adhere  to  and  implement  sound 
fiduciary and financial management systems.  
 
21. 
The project implementation will be in line with the existing institutional setup involving the 
MOE and CTEVT, strengthening their respective roles in TVET management. The MOE will be 
responsible  for  activities  related  to  the  sector  road  map  and  results  framework,  TVET  fund 
mechanism,  and  TSDU  establishment.  The  CTEVT  will  implement  the  rest  of  the  activities  by 
building  on  the  capacity  and  experience  gained  during  the  Skills  for  Employment  Project.  The 
project will apply strong and close monitoring of results. It will establish regional M&E teams to 
ensure  access  to  all  providers.  It  will  provide  support  and  training  in  government  and  ADB 
financial and procurement rules, disbursement, and reporting. In recognition of the fiduciary risk,

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

Economic and Financial 

 
A. 
 
26. 
The  project’s  economic  benefits  would  come  mainly  from  the  higher  wages  that  skilled 
workers can earn compared with unskilled workers. Other benefits, such as the multiplier effect 
from  the  increased  income  level  of  trained  workers  and  overall  productivity  increase  in  the 
economy are not included in the incremental benefits. The cumulative net incremental benefits 
become positive within 5 years of implementation. The project’s economic internal rate of return 
is  estimated  at  35%  and  remains  well  above  12%  in  different scenarios.20
 This  high  economic 
internal rate of return reflects the shortage of skilled workers in Nepal. 
 
27. 
The  financial  analysis  assessed  the  sustainability  of  the  project  at  national  and  project 
levels, and evaluated the impact of the proposed investment given current and projected TVET 
funding  levels. 21
 The  analysis  concluded  that  the  government  has  the  capacity  to  absorb  and 
sustain  the  benefits  of  the  project  considering  the  increasing  budget  allocation  for  TVET,  the 
efficiency  gains  from  better  utilization  of  existing  facility  and  upgraded  human  resources,  and 
expansion of fee-based training programs. For short-term training, however, the government will 
need to allocate additional financing to continue providing the target population with access to 
skills development opportunities and employment.

 Governance  

Poverty and Social 

B. 
 
28. 
Project-specific  governance  risks  have  been  identified  through  financial  management 
and  procurement  capacity  assessments  of  the  MOE  and  CTEVT  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Financial  Management  and  Analysis  of  Projects  and  Financial  Due  Diligence:  A  Methodology 
Note.22
 The assessments were informed by implementation of the Skills for Employment Project 
as  well  as  sector  and  country  governance  risk  assessments.  The  assessments  identified 
weaknesses  in  (i)  compliance  with  rules  and  procedures;  (ii)  staff  capacity  in  accounting  and 
internal  audit;  and  (iii)  financial  reporting,  oversight,  and  accountability.  To  address  the 
weaknesses,  the  project  will  train  the  project  staff  in  government  and  ADB  financial  and 
procurement  rules,  and  provide  detailed  statement  of  audit  needs  for  audited  financial 
statements  to  be  better  aligned  with  international  accounting  and  auditing  standards.  A  third 
party  will  conduct  annual  fiduciary  reviews,  which  include  risk  update  and  post-procurement 
audit  to  help  identify  and  improve  government  capacity  to  manage  associated  risks.  The 
independent monitoring of training provision and verification of employment will not only provide 
comfort on the outputs achieved, but also indirectly on the uses of funds.  
 
29. 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with  the  government.  The  specific  policy  requirements  and  supplementary  measures  are 
described in the project administration manual. 
  
C. 
 
30. 
Despite  the  recent  progress  in  poverty  reduction,  more  than  25%  of  people  live  under 
the  national  poverty  line,  and  disparities  in  income  and  non-income  poverty  persist  between 
men  and  women;  urban  and  rural  areas;  and  across  different  social,  ethnic,  and  religious 
groups.  The  poverty  is  highly  correlated  with  low  human  resource  levels  in  areas  such  as 
literacy,  education,  and  productive  skills.  A  gender  and  social  inclusion  analysis  of  TVET 
concludes  that  women  and  people  from  excluded  groups  face  obstacles  in  accessing  skills 
development opportunities because of multifaceted barriers.23 Employment-linked skills training 
in occupations in high demand will allow unemployed and underemployed target beneficiaries to 
find  gainful  employment,  thus  contributing  to  poverty  reduction  and  social  empowerment.  The 
project design incorporates measures to increase women’s and excluded groups’ enrollment in 
nontraditional  skills  training  and  their  employment  in  the  construction,  manufacturing,  and 
services  sectors,  through  social  marketing  and  mobilization,  outreach,  pre-  and  post-training 
services  (counseling  and  employment  services),  and  affirmative  action  such  as  scholarships 
and quota. Higher performance payments will be given to training providers for training and job 
placement of women and people from excluded groups. A gender equality and social inclusion 
action plan is developed to guide project implementation and M&E.24
